Row 2: 1 0 0 1  
Row 3: 1 0 0 0

• (1,1)  
• (2,1)  
• (2,2)  
• (3,1)

To check quickly:
1. Pressing (1,1) toggles (1,1) plus its adjacent cells (0,1), (1,0), (1,2), and (2,1).

3. Pressing (2,2) toggles (2,2) and its neighbors (1,2), (2,1), (2,3), and (3,2).  
4. Finally, pressing (3,1) toggles (3,1) and its neighbors (2,1), (3,0), and (3,2).

A careful simulation shows that after these moves all lights are turned off.

We can solve the puzzle “Lights Out” on the given board by “working row‐by‐row”. One possible solution is as follows. First note that the board (numbered with rows 0–3 and columns 0–3) is

 Row 0: 0 1 1 0  
 Row 1: 1 0 1 1  
 Row 2: 1 0 1 0  
 Row 3: 1 0 1 0

One idea is to “clear” the top row by “fixing” every lit cell with a press in the row beneath. In our solution we decide not to press anything in Row 0. Then, since in Row 0 the lights at columns 1 and 2 are on (that is, cells (0,1) and (0,2) are 1) we press the two “buttons” right under them—that is, press (1,1) and press (1,2). (Remember that pressing a cell toggles itself and its neighbors up, down, left and right.)

Simulating these two presses we have:
 • Press (1,1) toggles cells (1,1), (0,1), (2,1) and also (1,0) and (1,2).  
 • Then press (1,2) toggles cells (1,2), (0,2), (2,2) and also (1,1) and (1,3).

After these moves the entire Row 0 is cleared.  
Next, we look at Row 1; now its only on–light is (1,2) (which got “turned on” by the previous steps). So we press below in Row 2: press (2,2). This press toggles (2,2) itself, its vertical neighbors (1,2) and (3,2), and its horizontal neighbors (2,1) and (2,3). After this press Row 1 becomes all zeros.

At this point the board looks like:
 Row 0: 0 0 0 0  
 Row 1: 0 0 0 0  
 Row 2: 1  ? 1 1  (the question mark “?” means the cell has been toggled to 0 if it was 1 – after checking, Row 2 becomes 1,0,1,1)  
 Row 3: 1 0 1 0

Finally, we “clear” Row 2 by “fixing” its lit cells in Row 3. In Row 2 the on–lights now occur at columns 0, 2 and 3. So we press (3,0), (3,2) and (3,3) in Row 3. (For example, press (3,0) toggles (3,0) itself together with its neighbors (2,0) and (3,1); pressing (3,2) and (3,3) similarly “push” the unwanted ones off.)

A quick simulation shows that after these moves all cells become 0. (Since the effect “adds mod2” the order does not matter.) 

Thus one valid series of moves to switch off all lights is:
 (1,1), (1,2), (2,2), (3,0), (3,2) and (3,3).

I will show one way to “clear” the board. (There is more than one possible solution.) One method is to use a “row‐by‐row elimination” strategy. (For example, with a 4×4 board the idea is to choose moves on row 0 arbitrarily and then select moves on row 1 to cancel any lit lights from row 0, then use row 2 moves to “fix” row 1, etc.) In our board the rows (numbered 0–3) read as follows:

 Row0: 0 1 0 0  
 Row1: 0 1 0 1  
 Row2: 0 1 1 0  
 Row3: 0 0 0 0

That is, the lights that are ON (shown by “1”) are at positions (0,1), (1,1), (1,3), (2,1) and (2,2).

One solution found by the elimination method is as follows:

1. Notice row 0 has a “1” at (0,1). In the standard strategy one “fixes” a lit cell in row r by pressing the cell just below it (on row r+1, same column). So we press (1,1). This has the following effects:
 – It toggles (1,1) as well as its adjacent cells (0,1), (1,0), (1,2) and (2,1). In particular, the (0,1) light is turned off.
 
2. Now look at row 1 (after that move, the remaining “on” cells in row 1 were at (1,0), (1,2) and (1,3); the press at (1,1) already cancelled (1,1)). To cancel these, we press on row 2 in the corresponding columns:
 – Press (2,0) to fix (1,0),
 – Press (2,2) to fix (1,2),
 – Press (2,3) to fix (1,3).

3. These row-2 presses change row 2 as well. Recalculating (after the moves from rows 1 and 2) the “on” cells in row 2 turn out to be at (2,0) and (2,2) are toggled by the moves so far; one finds that (2,0) and (2,2) are not yet completely fixed. In our working the net effect (when taken mod2) leaves row 2 with (2,0) and (2,2) still “on” (or rather, with a leftover if not fixed by further moves)—and also (2,2) may need another toggle. To fix the remaining lights in row 2 the standard procedure is to use the row below it (row 3). In our solution, we choose:
 – Press (3,0) to cancel the effect at (2,0),
 – Press (3,2) to cancel the remaining light contributed at (2,2).

When you check (each press toggles its own cell and the four orthogonal neighbours) the sequence of moves
 (1,1), (2,0), (2,2), (2,3), (3,0), (3,2)
turns all the lights off.

Thus, one valid sequence of button-presses is: (1,1), (2,0), (2,2), (2,3), (3,0), (3,2).

We can solve the Lights Out puzzle by “setting up” the equations over GF(2) (i.e. doing arithmetic modulo 2) so that the sum (mod 2) of press effects on every cell equals the initial "on" state. (A light that is “1” must be toggled an odd number of times so that it becomes 0; a “0” must be toggled an even number of times—including zero—so that it remains off.) One way to find a solution is as follows.

The board with coordinates and initial state is:
 Row 0: (0,0)=1, (0,1)=1, (0,2)=0
 Row 1: (1,0)=1, (1,1)=1, (1,2)=1
 Row 2: (2,0)=0, (2,1)=0, (2,2)=0

Pressing a cell toggles that cell and its neighbors (above, below, left, right).

One approach is to set variables p₍ᵢ,ⱼ₎ for pressing cell (i, j) (where 1 means “press” and 0 means “don’t press”) and then write an equation for every cell stating that the sum modulo 2 of the presses that affect it equals the initial state (with 1 for “on”). For example, for cell (0,0) the equation is:
 p₍0,0₎ + p₍0,1₎ + p₍1,0₎ ≡ 1 (mod 2).

Doing this for all 9 cells produces a system of 9 linear equations modulo 2. By reducing the system, we eventually find one valid solution (there are several). One such solution is to press the cells corresponding to:

 (0,1), (1,2), (2,0) and (2,1).

Let’s do a brief check (order does not matter since toggling is commutative modulo 2):

1. Press (0,1): toggles (0,1) itself, and its neighbors (0,0), (0,2) and (1,1).
2. Press (1,2): toggles (1,2) itself, and (0,2), (1,1) and (2,2).
3. Press (2,0): toggles (2,0) itself, and (1,0) and (2,1).
4. Press (2,1): toggles (2,1) itself, and (1,1), (2,0) and (2,2).

If you add up (mod 2) the toggles for each cell over these presses, you will see that every cell is toggled the proper number of times (odd if initially “1”, even if initially “0”) so that the final board is all zeros.

Thus one correct series of moves is:
 (0,1), (1,2), (2,0), (2,1)

Answer: (0,1), (1,2), (2,0), (2,1)

For instance, denote the unknown move at cell (i, j) as X(i, j). Writing an equation modulo 2 for each light we get, for the top left cell (0,0):
  X(0,0) + X(0,1) + X(1,0) ≡ initial(0,0) = 0 
and similarly for every cell. (Here we require that “1 + 1 = 0” mod 2.) By doing the linear algebra (over GF(2)) one finds that a valid solution is to press the buttons at

• Press (0,1) toggles (0,1), (0,0), (0,2) and (1,1).

• Press (3,2) toggles (3,2), (2,2), (3,1) and (3,3).

For example, row0’s only lit cell was at (0,3); the moves that affect (0,3) are only from the press at (0,3) so that one “1” becomes “0.” A similar cancellation happens in every row.

Thus after these six moves every light is off.

We can model the game “Lights Out” as a system of equations mod2. (Pressing switches commutes and is its own inverse.) In our 4×4 board the rows and columns are numbered 0–3 and the board is

 Row0: 0 0 0 0
 Row1: 1 0 1 0
 Row2: 1 0 0 0
 Row3: 1 1 1 0

Pressing a cell (r,c) toggles itself and any neighbor immediately above, below, left or right (if within the board).

One way to solve the puzzle is to assign a variable x(r,c) = 1 when you press cell (r,c) and 0 when not. Then the final state (mod2) of cell (i,j) is

  B(i,j) + x(i,j) + x(i–1,j) + x(i+1,j) + x(i,j–1) + x(i,j+1) = 0 (mod2)

where B(i,j) is the given initial on/off (1/0). Writing out 16 such equations and “solving” them mod2 produces many valid solutions. (Presses commute so the order is irrelevant.)

A possible (and valid) solution turns out to be to press just these cells:
 (2,0), (2,2), (3,2), (3,3)

• Start with the board

• Finally, pressing (3,3) toggles (3,3), (2,3) and (3,2). In the end, every cell becomes 0.

Thus, these four button presses successfully turn every light off.

  1 0 1

When you press a cell, that cell and its (up to four) neighbors (up, down, left, right) toggle their states. Our goal is to choose a set of presses so that all lights become “0”.

One effective method is to let p(ij) be 1 if we press cell (i,j) (and 0 otherwise). Pressing a cell will add (mod2) “1” to itself and its neighbors. Setting up the equations row by row (mod2) and adopting the “press the row below to fix the row above” strategy gives us a system with some free parameters. (There are several solutions, so any correct one is acceptable.)

After solving the equations (details omitted for brevity), one solution is found by choosing the free parameter a = 0. In our notation let

  a = p(0,0), b = p(0,1), c = p(0,2);
  d = p(1,0), e = p(1,1), f = p(1,2);
  g = p(2,0), h = p(2,1), i = p(2,2).

The system turns out to have the solution

  p(0,0) = 0,
  p(0,1) = 1,
  p(0,2) = 1,
  p(1,0) = 0,
  p(1,1) = 1,
  p(1,2) = 1,
  p(2,0) = 1,
  p(2,1) = 0,
  p(2,2) = 0.

Thus the cells we press are (0,1), (0,2), (1,1), (1,2) and (2,0).

• Press (0,2) then (1,1) then (1,2) then (2,0) and you can verify step‐by‐step that all lights are switched off.

Thus one acceptable answer is:

 (0,0) (0,1) (0,2)
 (1,0) (1,1) (1,2)
 (2,0) (2,1) (2,2)

The initial board is:
 1 0 0
 1 1 1
 1 1 1

Let “pressing” a cell be represented by a 1 (if pressed) or 0 (if not) and write the equations for each cell modulo 2. For example, the light at (0,0) is toggled by pressing at (0,0), (0,1), and (1,0) and must satisfy:
 (press (0,0)) + (press (0,1)) + (press (1,0)) ≡ 1 (mod 2)
because its initial state is 1.

Proceeding in this way, we obtain a system of 9 equations in 9 variables, one for each grid position. (A brief outline of the steps is as follows:)

1. Write equations for each cell using the fact that pressing at a cell toggles itself and its (up, down, left, right) neighbors.
2. For instance:
 • For (0,0): a + b + d = 1.
 • For (0,1): a + b + c + e = 0.
 • For (0,2): b + c + f = 0.
 • For (1,0): a + d + e + g = 1.
 • etc.
3. Substitute and simplify (using modulo 2 arithmetic) until a unique solution is found.

Following the algebra (details omitted here for brevity), one correct solution is to press only at (1,0) and at (2,2).

To verify:
• Pressing (1,0) toggles (1,0), (0,0), (2,0), and (1,1).

 we get after (1,0):  
  Row0: [0,0,0],  
  Row1: [0,0,1],

• Then pressing (2,2) toggles (2,2), (1,2), and (2,1), turning the remaining ons off:  
 Row1: [0,0,0], Row2: [0,0,0].

Thus all lights are off.

response:
We can solve this Lights Out puzzle on the 4×4 board by “working down” from the top row. One approach is to “fix” the rows one‐by‐one. For example, we can decide not to press any button in row 0 (i.e. set row 0 presses to 0). Then, noting that a press at a cell toggles the light at that cell and its immediate neighbors (up, down, left and right), we see that the lights in row 0 are affected only by a press in row 0 (neighbors left/right) and by presses directly below in row 1. Since every light must end “off” (i.e. sum mod 2 equals 0) and the initial state of row 0 is 1 1 1 1, we must cancel that “1” in each cell by choosing row 1 presses as follows:

• For cell (0,0): only row 1’s (1,0) can cancel its “1”. So set (1,0)=1.
• For (0,1): (1,1) must be pressed, so (1,1)=1.
• For (0,2): require (1,2)=1.
• For (0,3): require (1,3)=1.

Thus row 1 becomes: 1 1 1 1.

Next, we “fix” row 1. Write down the effect on a given cell in row 1 from:
 – its own press from row 1,
 – its neighbors within row 1 (left/right),
 – the press in row 0 (already chosen: all zeros), and
 – the press from the next row, row 2.

Working cell‐by‐cell we get (after doing the parity sums modulo 2):

• (1,0): initial 1 plus (1,0)=1 and right neighbor (1,1)=1 gives 1+1+1 = 1 (mod 2), so we must select (2,0)=1.
• (1,1): initial 0 plus (1,1)=1, left (1,0)=1, right (1,2)=1 gives 1+1+1 = 1, so (2,1)=1.
• (1,2): initial 1 plus (1,2)=1, and its neighbors (1,1)=1 and (1,3)=1 sum (with mod‑2 arithmetic) to 1 already, so (2,2)=0.
• (1,3): initial 0 plus (1,3)=1 and left (1,2)=1 gives 1+1 = 0, so (2,3)=0.

Thus row 2 becomes: 1 1 0 0.

Then, we fix row 2. Its cells are affected by row 1 (already set), row 2 itself and row 3 (yet to be determined). Working out each cell:

• (2,0): initial 0 plus from row 1 at (1,0)=1, row 2 (cell itself 1) and its right neighbor (2,1)=1 gives 1+1+1 = 1, so we need to press (3,0)=1.
• (2,1): initial 0 plus from row 1 at (1,1)=1, row 2’s (2,1)=1 and left (2,0)=1 gives 1+1+1 = 1, so (3,1)=1.
• (2,2): initial 1 plus (1,2)=1, plus row 2’s (2,2)=0 and left neighbor (2,1)=1 gives 1+1+0+1 = 1 (mod 2), so (3,2)=1.
• (2,3): initial 1 plus (1,3)=1 and (2,3)=0 (its left neighbor (2,2)=0) gives 1+1 = 0, so (3,3)=0.

Thus row 3 becomes: 1 1 1 0.

Finally, one can verify that the last row also ends up all “off” when adding the contributions from row 2 (already chosen), row 3, and the appropriate neighboring terms (note that cells on the border have fewer neighbors). One may check, for example, that for (3,0):
 initial 1 + (2,0)=1 + (3,0)=1 + neighbor (3,1)=1 gives 1+1+1+1 = 0 mod 2.
A similar check shows all row 3 cells are cancelled.

To list the buttons we pressed (ignoring those we left at 0) we have:

Row 1: (1,0), (1,1), (1,2), (1,3)
Row 2: (2,0), (2,1)
Row 3: (3,0), (3,1), (3,2)

Thus one valid sequence of moves (order does not matter, since modulo‑2 addition is commutative) is:

(1,0), (1,1), (1,2), (1,3), (2,0), (2,1), (3,0), (3,1), (3,2)

Answer: (1,0), (1,1), (1,2), (1,3), (2,0), (2,1), (3,0), (3,1), (3,2)

We can “solve” this Lights Out puzzle by modeling the toggling rules as operations over GF(2) (i.e. modulo‐2 arithmetic) and “eliminating” rows one after the other. (There are many methods to get a solution; below is one way.) 

Note that although the original examples were for a 3×3 board, the board given here has four rows and four columns. We label rows 0–3 and columns 0–3 so that the top‐left light is (0,0) and the bottom‐right is (3,3).

The board is shown as follows (each digit represents a cell’s “on” (1) or “off” (0) state):

 Row0: 1 0 1 1  
 Row1: 1 0 0 1  
 Row2: 1 1 1 1  
 Row3: 1 0 1 1  

Recall that pressing a cell (i, j) toggles that cell and its (up, left, right, down) neighbors (if they exist).

One standard method to solve such puzzles is to “force” the rows one by one. In our scheme we define a press pattern X such that X(i,j)=1 if we press at (i,j) and 0 otherwise. The effect on a given cell is the sum (mod2) of its initial value plus contributions from any press that toggles it. (For interior cells these contributors are the press at the cell itself and those immediately above, below, left, and right.)

A common strategy is to choose a “first‐row” press pattern arbitrarily and then “force” presses on subsequent rows so that the row above ends up cleared (all 0’s). (One may show that an appropriate “first row” exists so that the final (last) row will be automatically turned off.) In our solution we choose a first‐row press pattern of all 0’s. (Other first–row choices would lead to different, but still valid, sequences.)

Then one computes in order:
 • For row 0 we require that the net toggle on (0,j) is 0 (i.e. off). Since the toggling on a 0th‑row cell comes from a press in row0 (neighbors left/right) and a press at (1,j) (from below), one “forces” the presses in row 1:
  For each j, set X(1,j) = B(0,j) + [X(0, j–1) + X(0,j) + X(0, j+1)] (all mod2).  
  With X(0,* ) all zeros and B(0,*) = [1,0,1,1] this gives X(1,0)=1, X(1,1)=0, X(1,2)=1, X(1,3)=1.
 
 • Next, for each cell in row 1 (which now “feels” the effect of row0 and row1), we force the press in row 2:
  For each j, set X(2,j) = B(1,j) + [X(0,j) + X(1,j–1) + X(1,j) + X(1,j+1)].
  Since B(1,*) = [1,0,0,1] and X(1,*) = [1,0,1,1], one obtains X(2,0)=0, X(2,1)=0, X(2,2)=0, X(2,3)=1.
 
 • Then for row 2, we force row 3:
  For each j, set X(3,j) = B(2,j) + [X(1,j) + X(2,j–1) + X(2,j) + X(2,j+1)].
  With B(2,*) = [1,1,1,1] and X(2,*) = [0,0,0,1] (and X(1,*) as before) one finds X(3,0)=0, X(3,1)=1, X(3,2)=1, X(3,3)=1.
 
 • Finally, one must check that after these presses the last row (row 3) comes out all off. (A cell (3,j) receives toggles from X(3,j), its horizontal neighbors in row 3 and the press X(2,j) from the row above.) A check shows that every cell in the last row becomes 0. 

Thus a valid press pattern is given by:
 Row0: 0  0  0  0  
 Row1: 1  0  1  1  
 Row2: 0  0  0  1  
 Row3: 0  1  1  1  

Since the order of button presses does not matter, one acceptable answer is to press on every cell where our press pattern equals 1. Listing these positions in (row, column) order we obtain:
 (1,0), (1,2), (1,3), (2,3), (3,1), (3,2), (3,3).

Many different solutions exist; the above is one valid answer.

Answer: (1,0), (1,2), (1,3), (2,3), (3,1), (3,2), (3,3)

We can solve the puzzle by “working downward” from the first row. In this explanation we use 0-indexed row and column numbers. Although there may be many valid solutions, one possible correct solution is the following.

Step 1. We note the board is now 4×4 (with rows 0–3 and columns 0–3) with initial state

 Row 0: 1 1 1 1  
 Row 1: 1 0 1 1  
 Row 2: 1 0 0 0  
 Row 3: 0 1 0 0

Since only a press in the row below affects a given row (aside from a press in the same row and lateral neighbors), one strategy is to fix row 0 by “correcting” it with presses in row 1. In our method we choose no presses in row 0 and then to “cancel” the lit lights in row 0 we press every corresponding button in row 1. (Because pressing (1,j) toggles the light directly above, i.e. (0,j).) In our case row 0 is all 1’s; hence we decide to press every button in row 1 – that is, (1,0), (1,1), (1,2) and (1,3).

Step 2. With row 1 now pressed and with the rules that a press toggles the light at its own cell plus those immediately up, down, left and right, we look at the new state in row 1. (Remember also that row 1’s state is affected not only by its own presses but also by presses from row 0 and (later) row 2.) Requiring that row 1 become all 0’s forces conditions on row 2. Working through the toggling effects (each toggle happens modulo 2) one finds that to cancel the remaining “on” lights in row 1 we must press (2,0), (2,1) and (2,3) (and not press (2,2)).

Step 3. Now the presses in row 1 and row 2 will have affected row 2. Examining row 2 (initially 1 0 0 0) we determine what is needed in row 3 so that row 2 ends all off. A similar analysis shows that we must press (3,1) and (3,2) (and leave (3,0) and (3,3) unpressed).

Step 4. Finally, one must verify that after applying all these button presses the last row (row 3) also results in all 0’s. A check shows that indeed the toggles from the presses in row 2 and row 3 leave row 3 off. (For instance, cell (3,1) is toggled by its own press, by adjacent presses from (3,2) and by the press above at (2,1); taking the initial value 1 plus these toggles gives an even number of toggles (modulo 2), so the light ends “off”.)

Thus one valid sequence of presses is as follows:
 Press row 1: (1,0), (1,1), (1,2), (1,3)
 Press row 2: (2,0), (2,1), (2,3)
 Press row 3: (3,1), (3,2)

You may press these buttons in any order (since the operations commute modulo 2). In the required answer format the moves are listed by coordinates separated by commas.

Below is one valid solution. One common method is to “clear” the grid one row after another. Starting with the given 4×4 board (where rows and columns are numbered starting at 0):

Initial board state:
 Row0: 1 1 1 1
 Row1: 1 0 0 1
 Row2: 0 1 0 0
 Row3: 1 1 1 0

A press toggles the light at that cell and its neighbors (up, down, left, right). One approach is to use the following procedure:

• For every “on” light in row 0, press the cell directly below (in row 1) to cancel it.
 – Row0 has all ones so press (1,0), (1,1), (1,2) and (1,3).

After these presses (simulate each step):
 – Press (1,0) toggles (1,0), (0,0), (2,0) and (1,1).
 – Press (1,1) toggles (1,1), (0,1), (2,1), (1,0) and (1,2).
 – Press (1,2) toggles (1,2), (0,2), (2,2), (1,1) and (1,3).
 – Press (1,3) toggles (1,3), (0,3), (2,3) and (1,2).

At that point row 0 becomes all off.

• Then, clear row 1 by “fixing” any on-light by pressing the cell in row 2 in the same column. In our simulation after the above moves, row 1 turned out to be all on so we press (2,0), (2,1), (2,2) and (2,3).

Simulating these presses:
 – Press (2,0) toggles (2,0), (1,0), (3,0) and (2,1).
 – Press (2,1) toggles (2,1), (1,1), (3,1), (2,0) and (2,2).
 – Press (2,2) toggles (2,2), (1,2), (3,2), (2,1) and (2,3).
 – Press (2,3) toggles (2,3), (1,3), (3,3) and (2,2).

After this, row 1 is all off.

• Now, fix row 2. In our simulation after the above moves row 2 had “on” lights at (2,0), (2,1) and (2,3) (while (2,2) was off). So we press the corresponding cells in row 3:
 – For (2,0) on, press (3,0).
 – For (2,1) on, press (3,1).
 – For (2,3) on, press (3,3).

Each press in row 3 toggles that cell plus its neighbors. After these moves, row 2 (and row 3) become all off.

Thus one complete valid move sequence is:
 (1,0), (1,1), (1,2), (1,3), (2,0), (2,1), (2,2), (2,3), (3,0), (3,1), (3,3).

The final board is all zeros.

  Row0: 1 1 0 0  
  Row1: 1 1 1 0  
  Row2: 1 0 1 0  
  Row3: 0 0 1 0

We label a cell’s row and column by (r, c) with r and c starting at 0 at the top‐left. When you press a light at (r, c) it toggles the light at (r, c) and its adjacent lights (up, down, left, right if they exist).

One way to “solve” the board is to “set up” equations row‐by‐row: choose the presses in row0 arbitrarily (free variables) and then force the row below to “clear” the lit cells created in the previous row. (This is how one solves “Lights Out” puzzles.) In our analysis we denote the press at (r, c) by P(r, c) ∈ {0,1} (1 means you press that button) and the effect on a cell is the sum (mod 2) of the initial value plus the contributions of the presses on that cell and on the adjacent ones. (Toggling twice does nothing.)

For the board we have, one systematic solution shows that the presses in subsequent rows are determined in terms of the top row’s four free variables. For simplicity we choose all free variables equal to 0:
  P(0,0)=0, P(0,1)=0, P(0,2)=0, P(0,3)=0.
Then the row–by–row analysis forces:
  Row1:
   P(1,0) = 1    (from cell (0,0)’s equation)
   P(1,1) = 1    (from cell (0,1))
   P(1,2) = 0    (from cell (0,2))
   P(1,3) = 0    (from cell (0,3))
  Row2:
   P(2,0) = 1    (from (1,0))
   P(2,1) = 1    (from (1,1))
   P(2,2) = 0    (from (1,2))
   P(2,3) = 0    (from (1,3))
  Row3:
   P(3,0) = 0  
   P(3,1) = 1  
   P(3,2) = 0  
   P(3,3) = 0

A quick “play‐through” of these presses shows they do indeed toggle lights in such a way that every light is eventually turned off. (For example, pressing (1,0) toggles (1,0), its right (1,1), its above (0,0) and below (2,0). Then pressing (1,1) toggles (1,1) plus (0,1), (1,0), (1,2) and (2,1); and so on. In the end every light ends as 0.)

We can “solve” Lights Out puzzles on any grid by writing the (mod 2) equations describing how each button press toggles the light in its own cell as well as those immediately above, below, left, and right of it. (All toggles are taken modulo 2 so that “off” is 0 and “on” is 1.)

For example, if we label the buttons in row i and column j as p(i,j) (with value 1 if you press that cell, and 0 if you don’t) and we label the initial pattern (again in mod 2) as L(i,j), then the final state at cell (i,j) is

  final(i,j) = L(i,j) + p(i,j) + p(i–1,j) + p(i+1,j) + p(i,j–1) + p(i,j+1)   (mod 2).

We require that every final(i,j) equals 0. (On the boundaries, the “missing” neighbors are simply omitted.)

In our given board we have a 4×4 grid with rows 0–3 and columns 0–3. The initial board is

  Row 0: 0 0 1 1  
  Row 1: 1 1 1 1  
  Row 2: 1 0 0 0  
  Row 3: 1 1 1 1  

One effective method is to “chase” the lights row‐by‐row. (The standard Lights Out procedure on a grid uses the free choice in the top row – then chooses the presses in each subsequent row in order to “cancel” the effect of the light above it.) One may choose many different free top‐row patterns. For example, one natural choice is to set all top‐row presses to 0 (i.e. not to press any light in row 0) and then force the rows below to “fix” the lights in the row immediately above. (You may check that not all free choices lead to a solution but for a 4×4 game there is always at least one solution.)

Working through the equations (or by using a computer–assisted linear–algebra approach in GF(2)) one correct solution is found by choosing no presses in row 0 and then determining the remaining moves as follows. (We denote the press at cell (row,column) as (r,c).)

The solution given by one correct set of moves is:
 • Row 0: no presses.
 • Row 1: press at (1,2) and (1,3).
 • Row 2: press at (2,0), (2,2) and (2,3).
 • Row 3: press at (3,2) and (3,3).

One may verify by summing (mod 2) the contributions that every light ends up “off.”

Thus one correct answer is to press in the order (the order does not matter in a toggle puzzle):

(1,2), (1,3), (2,0), (2,2), (2,3), (3,2), (3,3)

Answer: (1,2), (1,3), (2,0), (2,2), (2,3), (3,2), (3,3)

A way to solve Lights Out is to “eliminate” lit lights row‐by-row. One common method is:  
• For every lit cell in row i, press the cell in row i+1 of the same column. (Because pressing the cell below toggles the light above.)

Step 1. Look at row0. It has lights at (0,1) and (0,2).  
• Pressing (1,1) will toggle (1,1) plus its neighbors: (0,1), (1,0), (1,2), and (2,1).  
• Pressing (1,2) will toggle (1,2) plus its neighbors: (0,2), (1,1), (1,3), and (2,2).

After these two presses the effect is (remember that toggles are mod2):  
– Row0 becomes all off.  
– Row1 becomes 1’s at positions (1,0), (1,1) (accumulated from the two overlapping toggles) and (1,3).  
– Row2 now has lights at (2,1) (from the first press) with (2,2) having been toggled off (since it started on and was toggled once).

So the board becomes:  
Row0: 0 0 0 0  
Row1: 1 1 0 1  
Row2: 0 1 0 0  
Row3: 0 0 0 0  

Step 2. Now “clear” row1 by acting on row2.  
Row1 currently has lit cells at (1,0), (1,1), and (1,3). To clear these, press in row2 in the same columns:  
• Press (2,0) to toggle (2,0) and its neighbors: (1,0), (2,1), and (3,0).  
• Press (2,1) to toggle (2,1) and its neighbors: (1,1), (2,0), (2,2), and (3,1).  
• Press (2,3) to toggle (2,3) and its neighbors: (1,3), (2,2), and (3,3).

After these three moves we update:  
– Row1 becomes all off.  
– Row2 becomes changed (now having lights that “leaked” from the toggles), and  
– Row3 picks up lights from the toggles on its top neighbors. 

A careful simulation gives:  
After (2,0):  
• Row1: (1,0) goes off.  
• Row2: (2,0) becomes on; (2,1) toggles off (it was on).  
• Row3: (3,0) becomes on.  

After (2,1):  
• Row1: (1,1) goes off.  
• Row2: (2,1) becomes on (again, because it was off after (2,0), but note (2,0) toggles back off here); (2,2) becomes on.  
• Row3: (3,1) becomes on.  

After (2,3):  
• Row1: (1,3) goes off.  
• Row2: (2,3) becomes on and (2,2) toggles off.  
• Row3: (3,3) becomes on.

At this point the board is:  
Row0: 0 0 0 0  
Row1: 0 0 0 0  
Row2: 0 1 0 1  
Row3: (lights from previous moves) where (3,0) = 1, (3,1) = 1, (3,3) = 1, and (3,2) remains 0.

Step 3. Now fix row2 using row3 presses.  
Row2 has lights at (2,1) and (2,3). We press the cells directly below in row3:  
• Press (3,1) to toggle (3,1) and its neighbors: (2,1), (3,0), (3,2).  
• Press (3,3) to toggle (3,3) and its neighbors: (2,3) and (3,2).

After pressing (3,1):  
• Row2: (2,1) becomes toggled off.  
• Row3: (3,0) and (3,1) become toggled (turn off if they were on), while (3,2) becomes on.  

After pressing (3,3):  
• Row2: (2,3) becomes toggled off.  
• Row3: (3,3) toggles off and (3,2) toggles back off.

After these moves the entire board becomes all zeros.

Thus, one valid sequence of moves is:  
(1,1), (1,2), (2,0), (2,1), (2,3), (3,1), (3,3).

Following the required format, the final output is:

Answer: (1,1), (1,2), (2,0), (2,1), (2,3), (3,1), (3,3)

response:
We start with the board (with rows and columns numbered from 0 to 3):

 Row0: 0 1 1 1  
 Row1: 1 0 0 1  
 Row2: 1 1 0 0  
 Row3: 0 1 0 1  

Remember that pressing a cell toggles that cell and its (up, down, left, right) neighbors. One common way to solve these “Lights Out” puzzles is to “clear” the board row‐by‐row. (There is no requirement to use the minimum number of moves; any valid sequence that turns all lights off is acceptable.)

Below is one way to obtain a solution. In our solution we decide not to press any button in row 0. Instead we “fix” row 0 by pressing buttons in row 1. Then we continue row‐by‐row and finally check that the last row (row 3) is all off. (All arithmetic is done mod 2 where 1 means “pressed” or “light on” and 0 means “not pressed” or “light off”.)

Let p[r][c] be 1 if we press at cell (r, c).

Step 1. Assume no buttons are pressed in row 0:
 p[0,0]=0, p[0,1]=0, p[0,2]=0, p[0,3]=0.

For each cell i in row 0, the light at (0,i) will be toggled by:
 – the (0,i) press (p[0,i]),
 – its left/right neighbors in row 0,
 – and the press in row 1 directly beneath it.
Because we set row 0 presses to 0, to “cancel” the lights initially on in row 0 we determine row 1 presses as follows:
 • For (0,0): It gets toggled only by p[1,0] (neighbors that exist). We need p[1,0] to be 0 (since b[0,0]=0), so p[1,0]=0.
 • For (0,1): The toggles affecting (0,1) come from p[0,1] (0), its left p[0,0] (0) and right p[0,2] (0) — so we require p[1,1]=b[0,1]=1.
 • For (0,2): Similarly, p[1,2]=b[0,2]=1.
 • For (0,3): p[1,3]=b[0,3]=1.

Thus, row 1 presses are:
 Row1: p[1,0]=0, p[1,1]=1, p[1,2]=1, p[1,3]=1.

Step 2. Now “clear” row 1 by deciding row 2 presses. For each cell in row 1 the light state (after already accounting for row 0 and row 1 presses) must be turned off. For example:

 For (1,0): Its togglers are:
  – p[1,0] (itself, =0),
  – above p[0,0] (=0),
  – left: none,
  – right: p[1,1] (=1),
  – below: p[2,0] (unknown).
 We need 0+0+1+p[2,0] ≡ b[1,0]. Since b[1,0]=1, we must have 1+p[2,0] ≡1 so p[2,0]=0.

 For (1,1): Togglers are:
  – p[1,1]=1,
  – above p[0,1]=0 (remember row 0 wasn’t pressed),
  – left p[1,0]=0,
  – right p[1,2]=1,
  – below p[2,1] (unknown).
 Sum = 1+0+0+1 + p[2,1] = 2+p[2,1] ≡ p[2,1] (since 2≡0 mod2). We require p[2,1] ≡ b[1,1]=0. So, p[2,1]=0.

 For (1,2): Togglers:
  – p[1,2]=1,
  – above p[0,2]=0,
  – left p[1,1]=1,
  – right p[1,3]=1,
  – below p[2,2] (unknown).
 Sum = 1+0+1+1+p[2,2] = 3+p[2,2] ≡ 1+p[2,2] (since 3 mod2=1). We want 1+p[2,2] ≡ b[1,2]=0, so p[2,2] must be 1.

 For (1,3): Togglers:
  – p[1,3]=1,
  – above p[0,3]=0,
  – left p[1,2]=1,
  – below p[2,3] (unknown; right nonexistent).
 Sum = 1+0+1+p[2,3] = 2+p[2,3] ≡ p[2,3]. This must equal b[1,3]=1, so p[2,3]=1.

Thus, row 2 presses become:
 Row2: p[2,0]=0, p[2,1]=0, p[2,2]=1, p[2,3]=1.

Step 3. Now decide row 3 presses (last row) so that row 2 lights are turned off.
For (2,0): Togglers affecting cell (2,0):
 – p[2,0]=0,
 – above p[1,0]=0,
 – right p[2,1]=0,
 – below p[3,0] (unknown),
 – left: none.
We need p[3,0] ≡ b[2,0]=1, so p[3,0]=1.

For (2,1): Togglers:
 – p[2,1]=0,
 – above p[1,1]=1,
 – left p[2,0]=0,
 – right p[2,2]=1,
 – below p[3,1] (unknown).
Sum = 0+1+0+1+p[3,1] = 2+p[3,1] ≡ p[3,1]. It must equal b[2,1]=1, so p[3,1]=1.

For (2,2): Togglers:
 – p[2,2]=1,
 – above p[1,2]=1,
 – left p[2,1]=0,
 – right p[2,3]=1,
 – below p[3,2] (unknown).
Sum = 1+1+0+1+p[3,2] = 3+p[3,2] ≡ 1+p[3,2]. We require 1+p[3,2] ≡ b[2,2]=0, hence p[3,2]=1.

For (2,3): Togglers:
 – p[2,3]=1,
 – above p[1,3]=1,
 – left p[2,2]=1,
 – below p[3,3] (unknown).
Sum = 1+1+1+p[3,3] = 3+p[3,3] ≡ 1+p[3,3]. Set 1+p[3,3] ≡ b[2,3]=0, so p[3,3]=1.

Thus, row 3 presses become:
 Row3: p[3,0]=1, p[3,1]=1, p[3,2]=1, p[3,3]=1.

Step 4. (Verification) Finally, we check that the last row (row 3) is all off when accounting for the toggles from row 3 itself and from the row above:
 For a boundary cell like (3,0): togglers are p[3,0] (1), above: p[2,0]=0, right: p[3,1]=1. Total = 1+0+1 = 2 ≡0 mod2, matching b[3,0]=0.
 A similar verification works for the other cells in row 3.

So one valid sequence of presses (nonzero entries of p) is:
 Row1: (1,1), (1,2), (1,3)
 Row2: (2,2), (2,3)
 Row3: (3,0), (3,1), (3,2), (3,3)

The order in which you press them does not matter (since toggling is commutative modulo 2). One acceptable answer is to list the moves in row–order.

Thus the answer is:

Answer: (1,1), (1,2), (1,3), (2,2), (2,3), (3,0), (3,1), (3,2), (3,3)
